Adobe we looked at what happens what do people do when they encounter a task they don't know how to do in a software
like Photoshop and in particular we had three research questions first how do
people approach looking for help where do they go do they ask a friend do they open the browser did they go to a search

useful and this this question is because we've looked at video and text and try
to understand what's useful about these different kinds of formats and we found that you know video there's tons of

instructional content format is preferred and then finally there are
lots and lots of examples out there of how to do things in software like Photoshop but are people able to take
these examples and translate them to their own task invariably the examples out there are
not exactly the same as what the user is trying to accomplish how easy is it for them to generalize those examples and
follow on with them in their own context so to answer these questions we brought
some people into the lab we asked them to do some tasks and we watched them and we asked them questions and they did one

Photoshop 3d tools you may not know this but Photoshop has 3d tools at inside of

what we're finding is that people are learning opportunistically they're opening pieces of software and assuming

video and watch it very carefully and be very slow and methodical and trying to

didn't fit the context of the user it was often hard to translate it and so what does it mean to not fit the context

the other problem was that the state of the application changes as you do the
tutorial and so if your state doesn't match the state of the tutorial then you
might see different menus and different things might be enabled and so users were often very confused when the thing
that that the tutorial would tell them to do was actually not available to them in their own applications and so we

started looking at editing with natural language we thought that natural language would give us two benefits one

a recognition module that runs directly on the device that's tuned with a finite vocabulary that's specific to the image
editing domain so that's something that's quite fast and can turn that speech into text quickly but of course
if the user uses words that aren't in our vocabulary then we need some way to turn that into text and so for that we
go to a general-purpose cloud service that gives us txt enter in return for

and figure out which part of the phrase has the image operation in which parts

shadows on the left side the adjective is slightly bright and once we have this
parse we compare it to a set of templates and its really the templates that tell us where the image operations
are and where the parameters are so here bright is actually what corresponds to
the image operation and that it's under the adjective the nouns tell
